etymologies: early 17th century (in an earlier sense). From (i) French affusion parenchyma;

definitions: The action or an act of pouring a liquid on to something or someone.

The pouring of water on the body or a part of the body for therapeutic purposes; an instance of this. Frequently with distinguishing word specifying the temperature of the water, especially in "cold affusion". Also figurative.

notes.text: Affusion of cold water was used commonly in the treatment of fevers until the early 20th century.

definitions: The administration of baptism by pouring or sprinkling water over a person's head (opposed to immersion and aspersion); an instance of this.

notes.text: Now the most usual form of baptism in the Roman Catholic and Anglican Churches.
